name: Annecy
fun_fact: Fun fact: Le Freti celebrated its 50th anniversary in 2024â€”since 1974, this mountain chalet restaurant has been serving 15 different types of fondue and 8 raclette variations using only raw milk farmhouse cheeses, making it the cheese cathedral of the French Alps.

hero_dishes.name: Tartiflette at Le Freti
hero_dishes.description: Sliced potatoes baked with Reblochon cheese, lardons, and onions until bubbling and goldenâ€”pure Alpine indulgence
hero_dishes.origin_story: Le Freti has been the benchmark for Savoyard cheese dishes since 1974. Tartiflette uses local Reblochon cheese (the name means 'to pinch again,' referring to making cheese from second milking). Everything is homemade with raw milk farmhouse cheeses
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Le Freti (celebrating 50 years in 2024), Chez Mamie Lise (cozy chalet atmosphere), Le Chalet, or Le Ramoneur Savoyard in Old Town

hero_dishes.name: Raclette at Chez Mamie Lise
hero_dishes.description: Melted cheese scraped onto boiled potatoes, served with charcuterie and picklesâ€”simple, social, and incredibly satisfying
hero_dishes.origin_story: Chez Mamie Lise is famous for its intimate chalet atmosphere and traditional cheese dishes. The raclette uses cheeses from Val d'Arly dairy. The name comes from the French word 'racler' (to scrape)â€”you scrape melted cheese onto your plate
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Chez Mamie Lise (book ahead!), Le Freti, or Le Chalet in Old Town

hero_dishes.name: Fondue Savoyarde
hero_dishes.description: Melted GruyÃ¨re, ComtÃ©, and Beaufort cheese with white wine and garlicâ€”served in a communal pot for dipping bread
hero_dishes.origin_story: Le Freti offers 15 different fondue variations, but the classic Savoyard version uses three cheeses. The ritual is communal: if you drop your bread in the pot, tradition says you buy the next round of wine
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Le Freti (15 fondue varieties), Chez Mamie Lise, Le Chalet, or any Savoyard restaurant

hero_dishes.name: Diots au Vin Blanc
hero_dishes.description: Savoyard sausages cooked in white wine with onionsâ€”rustic, hearty, mountain food
hero_dishes.origin_story: Diots are the traditional sausages of Savoie, cooked slowly in local white wine until tender. They're less refined than city food, which is exactly the pointâ€”this is what mountain people ate
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Traditional Savoyard restaurants, especially Le Freti and Le Chalet

signature_drinks.description: Crisp, mineral white wine from Savoie vineyardsâ€”perfect for cutting through cheese
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Always paired with fondue, raclette, or tartiflette. The acidity cuts through the richness of melted cheese. Locals drink it chilled in wine glasses at mountain chalets
